text:
On September 30th, 1965,
some friends of mine and I
were drinking cheap wine.
And I was angry.

One of my friends,
one of my gang members

had been killed not
too long before that.
We encountered Mr. White.

Had no indication that he
was actually from a gang.

I thought he was but later found
out that he probably was not.

And after a few
words, I shot him.

He died, probably right
there on the scene,
and it was just a senseless act.

And I wish I could
go back and undo it.

I wish it would
never have happened.

And I regret it
every single day.

My best friend, when I was
incarcerated the last time,

just got out about,
almost two years ago,
after 52 years in prison.

He didn't do anything
any worse than I did.

He ended up doing 52 years
of his life in prison.

And I went to become the
president of the Portland Trail

Blazers, running
the Jordan brand.

And one of the things
that I struggled with,
the whole idea of, why me?

Of all the people I know,
of all the folks who

I was in and out of
jail with, all the folks

that I did criminal
stuff with, why

me to be the one that gets
to move to the situation

that I'm in or gets
to be where I am?

And I think part of the reason
why is to tell this story.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

All through elementary
school, I was

a straight-A student, teacher's
pet, that kind of deal.

And my goal was always to
please teachers and parents.

That lasted up until
around the time I

started middle school, which we
called junior high back then.

The guys in the street
were like the cool guys,
and that's what I wanted to be.

At the age of 12 years
old, I was the first time

I had an interaction
with the police.

A friend of mine
and I stole a bike.

That was the first time a
policeman pulled a gun on me.

I was running,
trying to get away,

and the cop pulled out
the gun and said, stop,
or I'll blow your brains out.
And I stopped, of course.

But that kind of started my
journey down the wrong path.

At that point, I started to
get more and more involved
in the street.

I joined a gang when I was,
like, 13, and from that point,

I just started to live this
life of crime, basically.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Even though I was 16 years
old, I was charged as an adult.

I ended up pleading guilty
to second-degree murder

and was sentenced to
4 and 1/2 to 20 years.

And so I was sentenced to
do my time at Camp Hill.

One of the older guys,
while I was there,

talked about using the
time to educate myself,
to learn things.

So I started reading,
and I got so hooked

on reading, that any
time I wasn't at work

or doing something,
I was reading a book.

And I mean, I read everything
from classics to westerns

to science fiction
to you name it,

because I just developed
this habit for reading.

I took classes to get
my GED, and I ended up
taking the GED exam.

And about a week
or so later, I was

in my cell, and the
guy who worked there,

who administered the exam,
he came down to my cell.
And he said, hey, how you doing?
I said, hey, I said, did I pass?

He said, not only
did you pass, but you

got one of the highest
scores I've ever seen.

He said, we'd like for you
to be the valedictorian

at the graduation
ceremony this year.

I'm like, man, I'm
not doing that.
I'm like, no.

I'm too cool to do that
kind of stuff, right?

The reality is, there were
a number of people there

who also were in
that same thing.

So we were cool, but we
were also about education

and about trying
to learn things.

And I talked to some
of my friends later,
and they were like, no, man.
You should do that.

They were like,
you should do that.

And I delivered the
valedictorian address
at the graduation.

I don't remember
the whole speech,

but I remember my last line, and
it was, "Let's not serve time.
Let's let time serve us."
So I did my 4-and-1/2.
Got out.

Kind of knocked
around for a while.

Was kind of in and
out of jail and still

hadn't figured out
what I wanted to do.

I ended up back in
jail with a number
of armed robbery charges.

I think I had five
armed robbery charges.

When I got to Graterford
Penitentiary, which

is where I ended
up doing that time,

they had a program there where
you could take college classes

inside the jail, and because
Pell Grants were available,

there were a number of
colleges that were teaching
classes inside the prison.

And then they had a program
there where you could qualify.

By taking classes, not
getting into trouble,

you could qualify to move
into these trailers that
were outside the jail wall.

And you lived in those
trailers and left every day
to go to school.
Had to be back by 8:00 at night.

And when I heard
about that program,

I'm like, man, that's
how I want to do my time.

If I've got to do time,
that's the best way to do it.

The two things that got
me through my last time

incarcerated were
religion and education.

Those are the two things
that made me believe
that I could change my life.

The sad thing is, that
program doesn't exist anymore.

The focus shifted
from rehabilitation.

It shifted to just
warehousing people,
to putting people in jail.

And hey, if we put them in
jail and throw the key away,

we don't have to worry
about them anymore.

And I think that shift
did away with a lot
of beneficial programs.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

The one I was
really interested in

was called Arthur
Andersen at the time.

I spent the whole day
interviewing with a number
of people throughout the day.

And all day, I'm
thinking to myself,

should I share my
background with these folks?

Should I really come clean and
open up about my background?

And so finally, I get
to the last person, who

was like the hiring
manager, and I decided
I'm going to share my story.

And as I was talking to him,
I could see his face changing.

And I'm like, I
don't think this is
going how I hoped it would go.

He said, wow, that's
an amazing story.

He said, I'm sure
you'll do great.

And he reached in his pocket
and pulled out an envelope.

He said, but I had an
offer letter here all

ready to give you, but I
can't give it to you now.

He said, I can't take the chance
on something happening down
the line.

So I wish you the best,
and I'm sure things
are going to work out for you.
But I can't give you the letter.

And at that point, I
decided that I was not
going to share my background.
I wasn't going to deny.

I wasn't going to lie
if there was a question,

but I wasn't going to
volunteer the information.

And that's the way I approached
my career for the next 40
years, basically.

For all of that
time, I was always

nervous and anxious and afraid
that it would somehow come out.

I had recurring nightmares
about going back

to jail for something
that I didn't know about.

I had migraines for
years to the point

where I had to end up in
the ER a couple times.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Through the course of that, I
got to meet some of the folks
at Nike.

One of the people
was a person named

Stephen Gomez, who was the
global head of Nike apparel.

He and I would get together,
like once a quarter or so,

just maybe have dinner
and talk about what
was going on with the business.

And I remember the last
time we had that dinner,

I remember driving
home thinking,

I feel like I just
got interviewed.
You know what I mean?

And sure enough, a couple weeks
later, Stephen called and said,

hey, would you have any interest
in coming to work for Nike?
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I was the first
Black vice president

in the history of Nike when
I started working there.

I did not realize that
until after I got there.

Michael Jordan was about
to retire from the Bulls
for the last time.

The formula was, we
design a cool shoe.

We do some advertising
with Spike Lee

or Bugs Bunny or
somebody, and then MJ

wears that shoe into 82
games and into the playoffs.

That was the formula
to sell the shoe.

And now that he's
retiring, you're

taking a big piece
of that formula out.

Well, no one had ever
taken a retired athlete

and said, OK, now we're going to
build a brand and now that he's
retired.

So there were a lot of
people who felt like, hey,

it was a nice run,
but that was it.

And I was then asked
to put a team together

and strategies on how we
were going to take that logo

and actually evolve
it into a brand.

Phil Knight accused me of
cherry-picking the organization
to put my team together.

At the time we started, the
Jordan business was about $140,

$150 million, and this
year it's over $5 billion.

So we figured out something
that kind of worked.

When I went to become the
president of the Portland Trail

Blazers, the reason I
took that job, in reality,

was that: how many
times is someone

who looks like me going
to have an opportunity
in a job like that?

And mainly to show
young people that

look like me that they
can do a job like that.

That was the main reason,
pretty much the reason
that I took that job.

The recidivism rate
is about 75%, 77%,

people who get
out and come back.

You know, 77% of people
who are incarcerated end
up back in at some point.

If people learn a trade while
they're incarcerated, that 77%
goes to 30%.

If they get a bachelor's
degree, that 77% goes to 6%.

And if they get a master's
degree, it goes to 0%.

So to me, that's
a clear indication

that education is a big
helper in getting people

to be able to change their
lives and to break out

of that cycle of:
You get arrested.
You go to jail.

You don't learn anything
or do anything that's
going to change your mentality.
You get out.

You do the same thing again,
and you're right back in.
And it's a vicious cycle.
I know.
I was caught up in that cycle.

Talent is distributed equally
but opportunity is not.

Some of the most intelligent,
creative, smart people

I've ever met are
people that I've

met inside the penitentiary,
because their situation

and their environment hasn't
allowed them to really express

and take advantage of that
talent, that God-given talent
that they have.

And I think, in a lot of cases,
that is shortchanging people,

and it's shortchanging
companies.

The street experience,
the jail experience,

it made me more able to deal
with situations that come up.

We have a problem with a shoe
selling or something like that,

and I'm like, well, I'm
not in front of a judge

trying to plead for my life
so we can figure this out.

I think people
have the perception

that someone who's
been incarcerated

is not going to be
a good employee.

They maybe don't
necessarily believe
they can trust that person.

What companies
need to realize is

that the people who are serious,
who come out of penitentiary

and are serious about
changing their life

and about making a
contribution, you're

not going to find anybody
that's more dedicated
and that's going to work harder.

There are so many people who
would jump at the opportunity

to change their
life if they really
believe that it was real.

I think that we need more
and more opportunities
like that for folks.

We were fortunate
enough to meet with some

of Mr. White's family, his son,
his daughter, and his sister.

Once we got to
that point, where I

was able to sit down
with them and tell them

how sorry I was and express
my remorse for what I did

and for them to
accept that from me

and to express the fact that
they are willing to forgive me

for it, to me, that
meant the world to me.

Again, I understand
why people would see it

as something that shouldn't
be and couldn't be forgiven.

I understand and recognize
the severity of what I did.

And again, I wish I could
go back and undo it.

I can't, but I can
express the fact

that it's something that
I live with every day

and that I'm sorry
for every day.
Mistakes are to be learned from.
You can't go back and undo it.

Now, you can just try to say,
OK, how can I move forward?

How can I try to make
up for what I did?

How can I try to
give back to offset
some of what it was that I did?

But again, I think that's
not an easy place to get to.

There's a guy named
B.J. Armstrong.

He used to play for the Bulls
when Michael Jordan was there.

We talked to B.J. about
M.J., about Michael Jordan.

And he said Michael
Jordan never lost a game.
He either won or he learned.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
